Welcome to Meriquai Falls, where Native American culture blends seemlessly with modern contemporary society to form one of the most beautiful cities in the United States. It is also home to one of the largest concentrations of metahuman activity in the Midwest. Between the schemes of Galvakar and his Imperions and the genocidal plots of the Manitou and his Totems of Retribution, the crazed antics of the Pooka King and the dark secrets of the Night Sparrow, there is plenty to do for an intrepid hero in Meriquai Falls. Save the city and perhaps, in so doing, save the world!

MEET CRIMSON-HAWK!

Although deceased, Crimson-Hawk was one of the greatest heroes in Meriquai Falls' history. Leader of the celebrated Omega Legion hero team, he was looked up to by many. Even after he was framed for a heinous crime and forced underground by the very people he swore to protect, he fought to uphold the virtues of his totem spirit, the Red Hawk, and the spirit mother of the Meriquai People, Grandmother Spider.

Meriquai Falls - Crimson-Hawk includes HERO System 6th Edition stats for the hero Crimson-Hawk, his anti-hero lover Sworddancer, and the villain Steel Hawk. Also included are discussions about Crimson-Hawk's mirror world counterpart, Blood Vulture, and the events behind the Fall From Grace.

184694.name: Abraxas
184694.description:
From publisher blurb:

How annoying do you have to be to get under the skin of things that don't have skin? Introducing Abraxas, someone every GM's players should learn to love ...love to hate that is.

Thief, liar, and all around nuisance who's managed to make the hit lists of pretty much everyone in the supernatural community. Good, bad, morally indifferent, it doesn't matter - they all despise him. Now it's your hero's turn to join the queue of entities looking for a piece of this guy.

Abraxas is a PL 11 threat to add to your Mutants & Masterminds campaign.

184695.name: Ratfolk!
184695.description:
From publisher blurb:

The Amazing Races PDFs introduce new archetypes, feats, character traits, racial traits, and archetypes for the core, featured, and uncommon races described in the Pathfinder Roleplaying Game: Advanced Race Guide. Every PDF contains two full pages of high quality content (no fluff or filler)!

Amazing Races: Ratfolk! includes new racial feats, ratfolk character traits, and alternate racial traits for ratfolk. In addition, this product features a new archetype for ratfolk rogues: the Street Rat!

184696.description:
From publisher blurb:

1985 is a story roleplaying game about a society of people enslaved by an authoritarian government. But unlike 1984 by George Orwell, the people of 1985 deserve everything they get. Asleep at the wheel for years and generally selfish miscreants, the people of 1985 need someone to control their lives. In a place where no one is free and nothing is left to chance, everything must be controlled. Characters are the regular members of the populace, spying on one another and reporting the offenses of their ‘comrades.’ They keep tabs on everyone else’s movements in a vain attempt to maintain Utopia.

Note: This is the fourth Protocol to play upon the fears of authoritarian control, but each has its niche. This one creates a world where dictums have slowly eroded freedoms. What has happened was avoidable. But it’s not any longer.

Protocol is a series of story roleplaying games that thrusts characters together into dramatic situations. Each game uses the same set of rules, with vastly different parameters, start points, characters, and finales. Players take on the roles of directors outside the action and characters inside the action, using the ebb and flow of four different scene-framing styles (vignettes, interrogations, interludes, and ensembles) to tell meaningful stories about characters in crisis.

Each game in the Protocol series is zero-prep for 3 or more players. The game length is exponentially long, so games with more players take more time to complete. The Protocol Series requires a deck of poker cards as well as tokens to track drama points.

184697.name: Advanced Lizardfolk
184697.description:
From publisher blurb:

Scale, Fang, and Claw

Cannibals in the swamp, lizardfolk are considered by many to be heartless savages and mindless brutes. Now you can go beyond that stereotype—or embrace it—like never before. Join this ancient race and bring a new kind of strength to your character.

Book of Heroic Races: Advanced Lizardfolk is the essential guide for playing a lizardfolk character. This 24-page supplement features:

Racial Traits to play a lizardfolk, 7 alternate racial traits and 5 new character traits to customize your character for this unique play experience
8 New Character Class Options including the tribal defender archetype, the cannibal bloodrager bloodline, the anointed one prestige class, and 3 new subdomains
18 New Feats including several expanding upon draconic heritage
3 New Magic Items and a New Spell
2 New Deities, each with a unique perspective on power and community for these tribal people
Details on lizardfolk adventurers as well as suggestions on how to incorporate this race into your world.

184699.description: 18 additional cards for Evolution. Origin of Species (compatible with all other expansions) and 6 cards for Evolution: Random Mutations.
184699.name: Evolution: Variation Mini-Expansion

184700.description:
In the Name of Odin is a strategy game for 2-5 players, each with a claim to become the new Jarl. You are all brave warriors, shrewd traders and bold explorers, but only one of you will become the new Jarl to rule in the name of Odin!

During the game, each player expends action cards to construct new buildings in their village, gather companions, recruit famous Vikings, and build longships that will carry them to fame and glory.
184700.name: In the Name of Odin

184703.name: DragonQuest Ultimate Character Sheet (XLS)
184703.description: Known by several names, including DQUCS, and DQ Ultimate Character Sheet, this MS Excel worksheet has multiple tabs ("Character Record", "Magic Record", "Combat Skills", "SKills", "Armor", and "More Tables") and formula that partially automate the character creation process for both DragonQuest and DQ Open Source.

184704.name: Dragonsgate College
184704.description:
Welcome to the school for exceptionally talented students of the ancient art of Dungeon Crawling! Are you ready to make your House proud?

Dragonsgate College is a strategic game utilizing a unique dice drafting mechanism, that puts 2-4 players in charge of Student Houses locked in a battle for recognition and prestige. Each turn players draft dice that allow them to perform multiple actions: recruiting new apprentices and teachers, placing new facilities on their player boards, and more. Each turn they also have the opportunity to raise the general skill levels of their House, in order to give their apprentices a greater push towards performing feats of bravery and cunning.

Constructing student facilities, hiring seasoned adventurers as teachers, dabbling in the arcane arts of wizardry and subterfuge, and cleverly outmaneuvering your opponents - all this awaits you within the walls of this ancient university. Prove your worth, and maybe you will even get a tenure!

184705.name: The Treasure of Socantri
184705.description:
From the introduction:

The DragonQuest game module, The Treasure of Socantri, is meant to be played in about 12 hours by four to six characters of adventurer level. It is designed to be presented as a single adventure, but can be easily incorporated into an ongoing campaign.

Before beginning the adventure, the GM should read and thoroughly familiarize himself with the background, layout and details of the stronghold, and the possible situations which may arise. He should compare the details of the occurrences within the stronghold with the maps so the story becomes firmly fixed in his mind.

This adventure can prove particularly deadly if the characters are mentally and physically unprepared. If the GM feels the characters are not ready for this challenge, he may wish to vary the abilities of the monsters or reduce their Fatigue and Endurance Characteristics to balance the encounters. If more than six characters participate or their abilities are too strong, the GM should add an extra monster or two.

184706.name: DragonQuest Game Master's Screen
184706.description:
User summary:

Released by the DQ Open Source consortium, the DragonQuest Game Master's Screen is intended as a replacement for SPI's commercially released screen.

The product was released as a set of seven MS DOC files for printing and user-assembly into a six-panel screen. Alternately, the documents can be used as reference materials.

The documents include these specific tables:
- 15.7, 17.6, 18.2, 65 (1 page)
- 18.3 (Grievous Injury; 1 page)
- 30.1 (Backfire) and 44.8 (Fright; 1 page)
- 63.1, 64, 83.4 (1 page)
- Adventure Tables (1 page)
- Equation Summary (1 page)
- Magic Tables (2 pages - intended for reference not screen)

184707.description:
Second expansion for Drizzit: il gioco di carte.
It includes:
3 new Adventure sets,
2 new Characters,
3 new sets of Enemies,
8 Muses

And the rules to play up to 6 players!
184707.name: Drizzit: il gioco di carte – Lame premurose e pozioni misteriose

184708.name: D-Quest
184708.description:
User summary:

Characters in D-Quest have three Basic Characteristics (Physique, Wits, and Lore) and three Derived Characteristics (Courage, Fortune, and Health Points). The Basic Characteristic values (-3 to +3) are purchased from a point pool. The Derived Characteristics are directly calculated from the Basic Characteristics (-3 to +3, except Health Points which range 6-18). Characters then purchase Skills with from a separate point pool (1 to 7). Skills allow characters to perform actions, including combat and magic use.

Task resolution is based on a Target Number (3-15), determined by the GM and modified by approach, being rolled against by d26. Characters with exceptionally good or poor Skill or Characteristic in the relevant area may get additional dice or simple modifiers. Combat works the same way, with armor and opponent ability possibly influencing the Target Number.

Characters gain Exploit Points through experience. Exploit Points accumulate and may be spent to raise a Basic Characteristic or gain/increase a Skill. Notably, simply maintaining "Master-level" or above values in a Skill requires the continual expenditure of Exploit Points.

boardgameintegration.174037: Firestorm Planetfall: Battle for Proteus Prime

184709.description:
Planetfall an explosive, fast paced game that brings ground-pounding, armoured combat to the ever-expanding Firestorm Galaxy.

In this deadly, hard sci-fi setting, hordes of futuristic tanks, agile aircraft and hulking mech-walkers tear each other asunder with high-powered weaponry. Lasers burn across the tabletop, rail-gun slugs smash through armoured hulls and advanced cyber-warfare weapons hack through vital systems – the war zones of the distant future are no place for the faint hearted.

Firestorm Planetfall puts you in the role of a Grand Commander, orchestrating the maneuvers of your chosen army. Each of your Battle Groups will contain several Helixes of stunningly-detailed 10mm scale miniatures, ranging from towering Leviathans to numerous bases of Infantry, all prepared to fight to the last under your command.

Your planetary invasion force will be formed of troops from one of the six core races, who in turn belong to one of two sides: the Zenian League or Alliance of Kurak, vast alliances currently fighting for dominance of the Galactic sector. Each of the six races has its own complex motivations within the conflict, as well as entirely unique vehicles and distinct ways of fighting their battles.


Firestorm Planetfall is a miniature tabletop wargame, set in the Firestorm Armada universe. The game uses 10mm miniatures and dice to reproduce future combat during planet invasion.

Firestorm Planetfall is a revised and updated version of Firestorm Invasion: Planetfall, with significant rules changes.

- Force construction is different and now uses the helix system,
- Reinforced Target Zone markers were removed,
- STAR cards were replaced by TACs (Tactical Action Cards), and - squadron activation no longer uses cards.

The helix system has also been blended into game play, in that you must activate every squadron within a helix before moving to another helix, and the turn structure is also different.
184709.name: Firestorm Planetfall

184710.name: Draft
184710.description:
User summary:

Draft is a generic, universal system that is not tied to any setting or genre. The game is based around using d10 dice, with higher scores being better than lower scores.

Characters have nine Main Attributes (Strength, Dexterity, Constitution, Reason, Intuition, Willpower, Charisma, Perception, and Empathy) in three categories (Physical, Mental, and Interactive). Main Attribute values range from 1 to 10; any attribute reduced to zero renders the character unplayable. Main Attribute values are purchased using a point pool. Characters may also have Special Abilities, Disadvantages, and Faults.

Characters have one or more Skills that allow them to perform specialized actions. Skill values range from zero (Untrained) to 10. Skills are purchased from a point pool and can increase through play (use). Skills are tied to a Main Attribute and the cost and performance may vary with that attribute's score. An example Skill list is provided. Skill checks are made on 1d10, modified by Skill rank and situational bonuses; this final value is compared to a target difficulty to determine success. Difficulty Levels range from 4 to 20. Opposed actions will have a Difficult Level that incorporates the opponents relevant Skills and bonuses.

Combat works much like a Skill but takes place in rounds and segments (6 and 2 seconds, respectively). Actions have duration in Segments and combat supports initiative. Weapons deliver "Impact" which is modified by Armor Type Protection prior to causing damage. Character wounding proceeds through set levels with wound Stacking. Special types of damage are considered (Falling, Suffocation) Combat also supports a variety of special actions (Parry, Dodge, Ranged Weapons, Cover, Charge, Hit Locations).

Although the system is intended to be universal and generic, the rules do have a brief section on Using Magic. Magic is said to have many "Branches" (schools). The goal of the section is not to present a complete magic system but to explain how such a system might be best incorporated into the framework of the rules.

184711.name: Das Trabrennspiel
184711.description:
This game consists of a cardboard folder. The inner left leaf has the rules and a pocket holding eight cards with numbered horses. The inner right has a spinning wheel with 21 wedges of different size in either red or black, each with an instruction to either put money into the pot or take money out. The rules say tokens like matches or nuts can be used instead of money. The numbers 1 to 8 are printed around the wheel, each with a thin black line leading to the wheel.

One player starts in charge of the wheel. Players choose their horses in turn, starting from the left of that player. For each race, the player in charge of the wheel closes the folder, turns a thick cardboard disk on the back of the folder that is attached to the wheel inside, and then puts the folder back on the table and opens it. Each player looks at where his number lies on the wheel and follows the instructions for that wedge. Because of the layout of the wheel, the result for each horse will be different. If a horse's number is directly on a line, that player does nothing.

The wheel-spinning duty rotates around the table. The rules suggest that the spinning player's horse is out of each race. After the agreed number of races have been run, whatever remains in the spot is split equally, and the player with the most tokens wins. If the pot ever runs out of tokens, the game ends immediately.

184712.name: Green: The Golf Card Game
184712.description:
This game has been published by dV Giochi as a reward for winning the 2014/2015 edition of the Gioco Inedito – Best Unpublished game contest. Powered by Lucca comics & Games and dV Giochi, the contest aims to identify the best new card game design from all prototypes received and to reward it by publishing the game in a fully professional and high-quality format, overseen directly by dV Giochi. All prototypes submitted must conform to the technical and style requirements, fixed components and a given theme which changes every year. Everybody can join the contest and this is a great opportunity for emerging game designers to see their idea published.
For more information:
giocoinedito@luccacomicsandgames.com
www.luccacomicsandgames.com

Description from the box:
The game of Golf cannot be won, only played. Or so they say...Use a tip from your caddie, and wait for the wind to turn favorable so you can reach the green.
Manage your clubs the best, and you could be the first to pocket your ball! It's easy:
1. Draw a golf club from the display or hit the ball to advance along the course
2. Spend your caddie tokens wisely to use the clubs special powers...
3. ...and try to pocket your ball using the fewest strokes possible to score the most victory points!

184713.name: Monopoly: Supernatural Join The Hunt
184713.description:
From the box:
Join Sam and Dean in the epic struggle against evil, and race to end the war between Heaven and Hell with the Supernatural edition of Monopoly.

This is a Hot Topic Exclusive Release.

184714.name: Epitome: Continuous Role Playing System
184714.description:
User summary:

Epitome is a generic, universal system (perhaps system component is more accurate) that attempts to allow completely free-form ("continuous") character development utilizing whatever methodology that an individual player desires. The core system describes a conceptualized process to create a character for any roleplaying system. The goal is not to assign values or points to discreet abilities or skills, but to generate a holistic character definition. The process emphasizes "visual thinking" over a mechanical, numeric approach. While these open rules are not for everyone, they definitely help create a vibrant, realistic character (which may then be ported into Attributes and Values, if needed).

184715.name: Terraform
184715.description:
Terraform is a relaxing turn based puzzle game set in the future. In the android version you will alter over 160 planets to allow settlements and forests to survive. Planets are made of hexagonal tiles that can be altered using many different tools and weathers. Use rain weather to fill a dried out lake with water, hot weather to prevent forests from expanding too far or burn them down, spread deserts and more.

Source: The Developer Website.

184716.name: Epitome Character Sheets
184716.description:
User summary:

Two character sheets are provided for Epitome. The are the same, except one is in color and one is black-and-white. They are provided as two one-page PDF documents. The Epitome character sheets are quite unique as they support the character creation methodology of the game.

The completed character sheet alone probably is insufficient for use in a traditional campaign game - but should serve to inform any secondary sheets needed.

184717.name: Exemplary Settings
184717.description:
User summary:

Epitome's Exemplary Settings examines a wide variety of commercially available RPG systems and explains how the Epitome character can be adapted for use with those systems. Each noted system includes a brief segment of rules though similar systems are grouped together. The document looks at these systems:

- Sword & Sorcery (D&D, AD&D, Rolemaster, RuneQuest, Stormbringer, Warhammer FRP)

- Contemporary (Call of Cthulhu, Conspiracy-X, Over the Edge)

- Space Opera (Star Trek, Star Wars, Traveller)

- Cyberpunk (Cyberpunk, Cyberspace, Shadowrun)

- Eastern Asia (Legend of the Five Rings, Sengoku)

- World of Darkness (First Version, Second Version)

184718.name: Lankhmar: Archetypes
184718.description:
From publisher blurb:

Bring the Twain—or those like them—to your table!

Featuring brilliant art by Aaron Acevedo, Chris Bivins, Bartomiej Fedyczak, and Jon Taylor, the Lankhmar Archetypes bring eight full-color, ready-to-play archetypes representing iconic characters from Fritz Lieber’s Lankhmar series. Better yet, each character has a layer for Novice and Seasoned stat blocks, making them twice as nice!

Included are: Rogue, Street Tough, Bravo, Thief, Ratling Black Sorcerer, White Magician, Fire Mage, and Ghoul Warrior.

184719.name: Savage Tales of Horror: Volume 1

rpg.2125: The Savage World of Solomon Kane

184719.description:
From publisher blurb:

Dare to wander the Black Forest in search of witches foul, where you may lose your soul…to the Face Snatchers!

Brave the bitter northern chill, where brain freeze is the least of your worries. At leastsomeone will keep those beautiful looks of yours in Cold Storage!

Relax for a lakeside Spring Break at The Retreat – if you can ignore the scratching at the door, and the deadly smiles of the townsfolk!

Investigate by gaslight the ghostly hauntings of the magnificent Manor of Blood. It’s very inviting, but doesn’t want you to leave!

The suspicious death of an old friend drives you to find answers somewhere in the Moonshine Blues of New Orleans, where mobsters and magic mingle!

Face Snatchers may be used in the Savage Worlds of Solomon Kane setting. Moonshine Blues may be used in the Deadlands Noir setting.

184720.name: Savage Tales of Horror: Volume 2
184720.description:
From publisher blurb:

In Love on a Mountain, the heart can be just as deadly as a gunslinger, and more tragic than a shot to the gut!

Missing livestock is blamed on wolves, but what is that sound at night, creeping from within the cracks…something that Skitters!

As part of an elite team sent to protect staff at an enigmatic Ice Hotel, there’s something evil that lurks in the frozen wastes, ancient and wanting…for Blood on Ice.

As players in a roleplaying game you love to fight demons and monsters as wizards and warriors. But what about when the LARP of Horror becomes all too real?

When the terraforming colony of Rosewood loses contact, your specialist team is sent to investigate. But what is this strange, creeping flora grown by the elusive colonists, and what is their dark secret?

Love on a Mountain may be used with the Deadlands setting. Rosewood may be used with The Last Parsec or Slipstream settings.

184721.name: Hexatome
184721.description:
From the introduction:

Hexatome is a role playing rules system, that is, it provides a set of rules needed to play role playing games. By role playing game standards Hextome's framework may be regarded as lean and sleek comprehending only those rules needed to smoothly run the game. Its rules aim at the players' freedom rather than complexity, but may be easily extended and adapted to specific personal needs.

User summary:

Hexatome is as light-weight as a rules system can be and still encompass an RPG. Characters are noted as being a "role" that is played like an actor takes on a role. No setting is provided, no resolution methodology is provided, and in fact only the character sheet guides character creation. The rules note that 6d6 are needed for play but their utilization is left up the GM, suggestion opposed actions are simply "diced for" with equal chances of success or failure.

The game is provided as an HTML file along with a downloadable one-page (A4-sized) PDF character sheet. The character sheet notes "Character", "Appearance", "Aims/Goals", "Relations", "Equipment", and "Wounds/Injuries". ALso noted are six Attributes: "Agility", "Presence", "Soul", "Physique", "Perception", and "Mind". A central hexagon connects the six Attributes. Among the Attributes, only "Perception" is sub-categorized--namely "Sight", "Hearing", "Smell", "Taste", and "Touch".

184722.name: Ludoku
184722.description:
In Ludoku the goal is to reach the end of the many levels with your Marble, using pullers, teleporters, jumpers and what not! Avoid the countless traps and solve every puzzle! Collect as many statues as you can!

Source: The Developer Website.

184723.description:
The adventure begins! Board the ship and visit every location in Rumini the brave little mouse's world! Fight the shark, shop in the bazaar of Pelevár, play poker in the Zsur Islands and reach three main ports before the others!

The game is based on the Hungarian writer Judit Berg's popular Rumini books. Before start the players are given different task sheets with the main locations they have to visit as quick as possible to win the game. Rolling three dice decides the direction and the distance the ships can go. All sorts of adventures are waiting for the sailors meeting dangers and friends which can be tackled with the help of some special cards. Good wind and well used tactics are all vital to reach first the final port...
184723.name: Rumini A Küldetés

184724.name: Fat Goblin Gazette (Issue 2 - Sep 2015)
184724.description:
From publisher blurb:

Fat Goblin Gazette is our new monthly newsletter covering all the amazing products we are working on, as well as giving you some free content, and showing off some books you might have missed. We will show off some of our website content, might do a contest, maybe even interviews. All the Fat Goblin Games freelancers are working hard developing new content for your grubby gamer hands, and this is where we will show off everything involved with that.

Not only will you see exciting things you might have missed, but you will also at times be privy to upcoming attractions and more importantly get an inside look at how we work.

Come experience each monthly installment and let us know what you want to see from us in the future!

184725.name: Storming the Heights, The Battle of the Alma, Crimea 1854
184725.description:
Storming the Heights, The Battle of the Alma, Crimea 1854 is a simulation of one of the first major battles of the Crimean War, fought on 20 September 1854. This game models for the first time in a highly-playable format the key elements of the battle — command control (lack of generalship), weaponry, and tactical formations — and aims to captivate players with its strikingly beautiful period map and counters designed by graphic artist, Terry Leeds.

GAME CONTENTS

• One 22" x 34" full-color, period-style map sheet
• One 1/2” full-color counter sheet
• One 5/8” full-color counter sheet
• One 3/4” wide full-color counter sheet
• Rules booklet with Designer’s Notes
• Two Player Aid Cards
• One 6-sided and one 10-sided die
• Boxed

GAME SCALE

Time: 30 minutes per turn
Map: 300 meters per hex
Units: infantry battalions, cavalry regiments, and artillery batteries
Complexity: Low to Moderate
Playing Time: 3–5 Hours
Number of Players: 1–2

Now available for preorder from Consim Press

184726.name: Murder in Stoneholme (Pathfinder)
184726.description:
From publisher blurb:

A Pathfinder Compatible Adventure for 4-6 Level 3 PCs

A refuge in the underworld, Stoneholme stands neutral, its dwarves refusing to participate in any of the myriad struggles which occupy their neighbors. But, of late, evil has come to Stoneholme. Still recovering from recent supernatural events, the city now finds itself facing a mysterious killer, one whose face is never the same twice, and who leaves his victims cruelly cut and torn. The PCs must find the evidence which links the murders to the Flintblade clan, infiltrate their dark manor and bring their gruesome deeds to an end. But more than fell traps fill this dwarven home. Demonic sorcery is at work and the PCs will need all their courage and strength to survive.

Murder in Stoneholme is a follow-up adventure to Dark Days in Stoneholme, but it can also be used as a stand-alone scenario. The adventure features a series of grisly murders, a dangerous dwarven manor, demon-worshiping dwarves and a demonic, shape-shifting murderer. Though set in Stoneholme, the adventure can be easily ported to any non-evil underworld city.

184727.name: Aristotle's Stairway
184727.description:
Aristotle’s Stairway abstractly portrays the philosophical pursuit of human excellence, of achieving “perfect being” as envisioned by the famous ancient Greek thinker Aristotle. Players roll dice and make important decisions, developing their powers of Reason, Ethics, Wisdom, Virtue and sense of Well Being while gaining various Insights along the way. The player who becomes more fully enlightened (gains the most Insight Points) will ultimately triumph – and win the game!

Generally, players will randomly select and roll three dice and use two of them to move their playing pieces up five colored columns -- sometimes taking scoring markers (IPs) -- until they reach one of the top spaces of each column. Some markers allow special modifications to a die roll. The game ends when one player has climbed all five "stairways" and thus has maximized all five powers as noted above.

Playable in 30 minutes, Aristotle’s Stairway is a cerebral, two-player filler with dice-rolling, tough decisions – and, with several catch-up mechanisms – usually results in a hotly contested, down-to-the-wire game!

184728.name: Outer Rim
184728.description:
For hundreds of years, humanity has been traveling through far galaxies. Many centuries ago humans encountered other sentient – yet alien – races, but only Kalmians were as aggressive and as technologically advanced as the descendants of the inhabitants of Earth. In the remote outer rim of the universe Tellurians and Kalmians keep fighting in their spaceships for domination. In those fierce and deadly skirmishes only a few things really count: commanders’ skills to maneuver huge astral vessels, the ability to foresee your opponent’s next move as well as wise management of energy in different ship sectors and proper assignment of power to shields and laser cannons.

Only one ship shall leave this accursed vastness of space, while the burnt-out wreck of its rival shall remain here as a warning to all enemies or a prized loot for lucky scrappers...

Outer Rim is a simple and quick, science-fiction battle game for two players. One player commands the starship of Tellurians, while the other player becomes the captain of the star vessel belonging to the alien race of Kalmians. Players wage a deadly duel in the cosmic space. Victory depends on proper allocation of energy around the starship, a little luck when rolling dice and smart use of special abilities of modules and crews.

The battle ends when one of the starships has two sectors destroyed. The commander of such vessel loses and his opponent wins!

184729.name: Name That...! Person, Place, Thing...
184729.description:
Name That...! Person, Place, Thing... is a quick thinking name game. Play individually or in teams.

Roll the dice in the dice unit, and write answers in the category shown in the center die that start with each of the letters shown on the outer dice. Only unique answers score points. Multiple word answers starting with the same letter score extra points.

36 categories on 3 category dice, plus 6 letter dice.

Note: This is not the same as Name That...! Person, Place, Thing..., even though it has the same name, and was published in the same year, by the same publisher.

184730.name: Carnivores
184730.description:
Carnivores, winner of the 2015 Best Combinatorial Game Award, is a 2 player strategy game where players control and evolve carnivorous species in a food web. They try to eat one another, and the player whose Carnivores fully expand into their ecosystem or eat a certain amount of flesh first wins.

The Carnivores in the game take the form of polyhexes on a hexagonal board, and a "Circle of Life" surrounding the board indicates which Carnivores can eat which.

Players evolve their Carnivores bit by bit, modifying them to take advantage of the food supply around them. But every modification also opens a species to predation from some other species. As a result players must navigate a perilous balance between aggression and self-protection to win.

Official Rules

184732.name: Catalyst Roleplaying Game
184732.description:
From the publisher's site:

Our world is crumbling. Demon armies have marched through their horrid portals on a genocidal campaign. As if the blood-thirsty monsters were not enough, a plague swept over the lands and claimed nearly every human left standing. Fate gave us control over the mysterious magical forces fueling the demon troops; those of us left may yet survive. Our civilization is ruined, our leaders are dead, and our hope is a fleeting dream.

Humanity needs a catalyst to change their course in this war. Join the tattered remains of our species in this long-form role playing game. Weave a rich story between a game master and a group of survivors in this alternate-present reality. Embody compelling characters with Catalyst’s classless character system. Engage in tense battles with our unique card-based combat. Attempt to save the world or just live to see the next day.

WHAT MAKES CATALYST DIFFERENT?

Setting: Catalyst's demon invasion is set in our world and during our time. You are not fighting on another planet; you are battling in your country. Instead of trekking through the Elf Forest, you are fleeing Denver through the Rocky Mountains looking for safe haven. Your group's favorite bar becomes the resistance's meeting point and the ornate church down the street is the headquarters of a demon-worshiping cult. The magic brought by the demons blends with the technology of modern humanity; survive in your city however you can.

Gameplay: Combat is card-based. Everyone in Catalyst simultaneously chooses a card representing their action, creating tension at every moment. Do you lash out with your knife and leave yourself open? Do you try to dodge, knowing the enemy is near-death, but a crossbow bolt from a single demon will end your life? Do you cast a powerful spell at a foe, betting on your quicker ally stunning them with deft crowbar hit? Revel in correctly reading the mind of your opponent or think up an impromptu backup plan when your friend unexpectedly runs away.

Characters: Be the character you want. Catalyst has no classes or professions. You decide who your character was before the demon invasion and what they become. Save the world as an autistic drug dealer with divination magic, a wannabe action hero who can throw foes with their mind, or a smooth talking frat bro able to cloak himself in darkness. Be the person the demons will learn to fear.

184733.name: Fourth World
184733.description:
From the Cherry Picked Games site:

In the post-demon world, humanity protects itself in the shells of metropolitan cities connected by rail. The town of Flagstaff hosts brave mercenaries dedicated to protecting these trains and keeping the demons at bay. "Fourth World" follows the players as they arrive in Northern Arizona and become embroiled in local politics, sinister plots, and ancient secrets that may save us once and for all.

This guide aids game masters in directing a Catalyst campaign. "Fourth World" takes 3-5 players through a longer, 7-session campaign.

184734.name: Runaways
184734.description:
From the Cherry Picked Games site:

Over a year has passed since the demons took Earth from humanity. Survivors cling to life outside of the demon-controlled cities, struggling to find food, warmth, and security. "Runaways" follows the players through this harsh reality as they escape a demon slave market and chase rumors of a safe haven across the Rocky Mountains.

This guide aids game masters in directing a Catalyst campaign. "Runaways" takes 3-5 players through a short, 4-session campaign.

184735.name: Shadow Parliament
184735.description:
From the Cherry Picked Games site:

Secret societies control the fate of humanity. A select few know magic, demons, and unlimited power exist. Some strive to bring forth these demons; others exist to protect our species. "Shadow Parliament" follows the players' induction into the Shadows and their clandestine efforts to prevent the cataclysm.

This guide aids game masters in directing a Catalyst campaign. "Shadow Parliament" takes 3-5 players through a longer, 7-session campaign.

184736.name: Fantastic Farm
184736.description:
User summary

This is a farming simulation/management game where you have to plant flowers and harvest them. You can creat bouquets to sell the flowers for a higher cost. You need to make money to rescue your parents.

184737.name: DragonSpawn
184737.description:
User summary:

DragonSpawn has a single document that is subtitled The Game Player's Guidebook. It was distributed freely on the internet.

DragonSpawn is a system that attempts to balance game mechanics with speed of play. The game uses standard characters but uses an "upside down" character creation process that attempts to generate the character prior to assigning numeric values to Attributes. Characters have twelve Attributes divided into three categories: Physical (Brawn, Stamina, Agility, and Manual Dexterity); Mental (Willpower, Knowledge, Thought, and Wisdom); and Social (Beauty, Leadership, Socialization, and Character).

Attribute values range from 1-30.

Characters also learn a variety of Skills that allow for special actions. There are numerous categories of Skill, each with various Skills. Characters note down each and every use of a Skill and at the end of each session use a formula and die roll to determine whether their Skill rank increases by one. Increases occur quickly at lower Skill levels and quite slowly at higher levels--levels range from 1-8. Combat, psionics, and magic use are all Skills. Note the system does not have a monolithic Skill resolution system--each Skill is treated individually.

184738.name: Gourmania
184738.description:
User summary

This is a combination of time management and hidden object game. You are trying to complete recipes and have to do the hidden object to find the ingredients.

184739.name: Sky Burger
184739.description:
User summary

You are trying to complete burgers for customers. You do this by tilting the device to catch the ingredients you need.

184740.name: Orient Express
184740.description:
User summary

You are trying to send the trains to the town they want to go to. You continue through levels until you crash enough times and have no money left.

184741.name: Piczle Lines
184741.description:
User summary

This is a puzzle game where you draw lines in order to form pictures. You have a particular number of spaces that you have to cover for each set of numbers. The trick or the game is to match the correct set of numbers and not the wrong ones.

184742.name: Sudoku 2
184742.description:
User summary

This is your typical sudoku puzzle app. It has five difficulty levels in the game, which determine how many numbers you start with in the puzzle.

184743.name: Ultra Violet Dawn
184743.description:
User summary

This is a game where you are trying to earn money by completing missions and trading cargo. You have to fly from planet to planet while protecting yourself from pirates and sometimes police if you end up on the wrong side of the law.

184744.name: Virtual Families 2: Our Dream House
184744.description:
User summary

This is a sim game where you adopt a sim, get them married and having children. You build up to repairing the house they start with to it's best state.

184746.name: DragonWizards Gamemaster's Guide
184746.description:
User summary:

There is no character creation process--all characters are pre-generated and players select them. Each character is presented on a Player Card. The players then equip their characters by spending money from a pool to purchase relatively mundane items from table lists, and spellcasters either draw or select spell cards. Game Cards then are drawn randomly from the deck as needed for the rules. Game Cards in turn drive the action, encounters, and so forth--effectively creating the adventure and campaign as it plays out.

The game is driven by cards, of which there are four types. Player Cards show characters, Monster Cards have several types of opponent, Game Cards drive the travel of the party, and Weapon Cards consist of equipment characters can use. Specific room contents are generated randomly when the room is entered, using a die roll to determine general room contents and then either consulting a table or drawing an appropriate card for specific contents. Table entries are selected by 1d100 and are generally basic or minor. Card entries are generally significant and major. Dungeon rooms contain traps, tricks, treasures, monsters, and/or equipment.

Combat is resolved by each participant rolling 1d10 to establish initiative. Hits are scored by 1d20, and wounds are determined by rolling 1d20.

184747.name: DragonWizards Player's Handbook
184747.description:
User summary:

The Player's Handbook includes most of the rules for the game but does not include any of the extensive random tables. The rules are presented with a focus on 'how to' for players. Several options are provided, for 1-3+ players. Also, an option for competition play is provided. The character selection and preparation process is noted. Each character receives a basic consideration and description. The document also includes spell and equipment lists with prices, and lists for available in-town services and prices. Campaign options are also provided to carry characters over multi-session play.

184748.name: DragonWizards Expansion Card Rules
184748.description:
User summary:

The expansion card packs introduce additional options to the game, but do note all applicable rules on the card faces. This document provides lists and tables which are suitable for use with the basic and expansion cards. These lists and tables replace those found in the original Gamemaster's Guide.

184749.name: DragonWizards Player Card Pack 1B
184749.description:
User summary:

Player Cards 1B is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 16 JPEG images, each one representing a character card. Characters are: Archer, Assassin, Druid, Fighter, Gladiator, Healer, Jeweler, Knight, Merchant, Monk, Ranger, Soothsayer, Sorcerer, Swordsman, Thief, and Wizard.

Card Pack 1B is different from Card Pack 2B only because the genders (and images) of every character are reversed in each pack, allowing players to use each character in either gender.

184750.name: DragonWizards Player Card Pack 2B
184750.description:
User summary:

Player Cards 2B is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 16 JPEG images, each one representing a character card. Characters are: Archer, Assassin, Druid, Fighter, Gladiator, Healer, Jeweler, Knight, Merchant, Monk, Ranger, Soothsayer, Sorcerer, Swordsman, Thief, and Wizard.

Card Pack 2B is different from Card Pack 1B only because the genders (and images) of every character are reversed in each pack, allowing players to use each character in either gender.

184751.name: DragonWizards Play Card Core Pack
184751.description:
User summary:

Play Card Core Pack is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 64 JPEG images, each one representing an adventure location. Locations include: Acropolis, Alien Artifact, Bank, Castle, Cave, Cemetery, Citadel, City, Colosseum, Crypt, Dragon Lair, Dungeon, Factory, Forest 1, Forest 2, Forest 3, Forest 4, Forest Path, Fortress, Haunted House, Hills 1, Hills 2, Hills 3, Hills 4, Hills 5, Hills 6, House, Ice Chasm, Islands, Kennel, Labyrinth, Magic Tree, Mansion, Maze, Monastery, Mountain 1, Mountain 2, Mountain 3, Mountain 4, Observatory, Ocean 1, Ocean 2, Ocean 3, Ocean 4, Old Building, Pagoda, Plains 1, Plains 2, Plains 3, Plains 4, Prison, Pyramid, Ruins, Silver Mine, Swamp 1, Swamp 2, Swamp 3, Swamp 4, Swamp 5, Swamp 6, Tavern Bar, Tower, Village, and Well.

Each card has play directions and a corresponding entry in the appropriate table in the Gamemaster's Guide.

184752.name: J'ai mon voyage
184752.description:
A fun and simple family board game. Each player gets two secret missions to save animals. These missions correspond to two specific tiles on the board. The goals are achieved by wisely using the set of actions available.

In his turn, a player plays one of his Action card and does the action described on the card. These actions consist of moving one or more tiles on the board, either up (Card+), down (cards-) or by switching two tiles (Switch cards).

A round can end either when a tile reaches the highest level or when all players have played all their Action cards.

Each player then reveals his two Mission cards and scores the number of points corresponding to the tiles drawn on each of his Mission cards

184753.name: DragonWizards Sword Card Pack
184753.description:
User summary:

Sword Card Pack is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 100 JPEG images, each one representing a piece of equipment that usually is related to combat in some way. Some example cards are: Mythical Mace, Pet Snake, King's Scepter, Elven Staff, Spellbook, Bastard Sword, Marine Trident, Skeleton Key, Lightning Ball Wand, and Wand of Trap Detection.

Each card has play directions and a corresponding entry in the appropriate table in the Gamemaster's Guide.

184754.name: DragonWizards Armor Card Pack
184754.description:
User summary:

Armor Card Pack is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 100 JPEG images, each one representing a piece of equipment that usually is related to adventuring in some way. Some example cards are: Arm Cloth Armor, Magical Shield, Ring of Armor, Longbow, Grapple Hook, Stone Hammer, Brass Knuckles, and Turquoise Gem.

Each card has play directions and a corresponding entry in the appropriate table in the Gamemaster's Guide.

184755.name: DragonWizards Monster Card Pack 1
184755.description:
User summary:

Monster Card Pack 1 is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 100 JPEG images, each one representing a monster or opponent. Some example cards are: Animorph, Cyclops, Elf Stormguard, Frog, Lizard, Swordsman, and Wolf.

Each card has play directions and a corresponding entry in the appropriate table in the Gamemaster's Guide.

184756.name: DragonWizards Monster Card Pack 2
184756.description:
User summary:

Monster Card Pack 2 is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 100 JPEG images, each one representing a monster or opponent. Some example cards are: Red Angel, Genie, Grinch, Halfling, Oxalis, Phobia, Spook, Toadling, Vampiress, and Zombie.

Each card has play directions and a corresponding entry in the appropriate table in the Gamemaster's Guide.

184757.name: DragonWizards Monster Card Pack 3
184757.description:
User summary:

Monster Card Pack 3 is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 100 JPEG images, each one representing a monster or opponent. Some example cards are: Acolyte, Centaur, Crypt Keeper, Dryad, Hobgoblin, Lizardman, Terrasque, Weeping Willow, and Wraith.

Each card has play directions and a corresponding entry in the appropriate table in the Gamemaster's Guide.

184758.name: DragonWizards Monster Card Pack 4 (Expansion)
184758.description:
User summary:

Monster Card Pack 4 (Expansion) is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 75 JPEG images, each one representing a monster or opponent. Some example cards are: Avian, Creeper Bug, Winged Demon, Imperial Elf, Frostbite, Lady in Waiting, Nixie, Rogue, and Yabbler.

Each card has play directions and a corresponding entry in the appropriate table in the Expansion Card Rules.

184759.name: DragonWizards Play Card Pack (Expansion)
184759.description:
User summary:

Play Card Pack (Expansion) is distributed as a .ZIP archive containing 20 JPEG images, each one representing a monster or opponent. Locations include: Army, Asylum, Barn, Blacksmith, Bridge, Church, Dock, Estate, Granary, Kingdom, Merchant Store, Outhouse, River, Sacred Stone, Step Pyramid, Temple, Tent, Time Warp, Volcano, and War Trench.

Each card has play directions and a corresponding entry in the appropriate table in the Expansion Card Rules.

184760.name: Small Market
184760.description:
A stock-holding micro game.

At start, all players will get the same amount of "price" card and "Merchandise" card, all cards present 5 merchandises in a combination of 2 kinds.

Players trade their hand cards until someone runs out his hand cards. Players multiplies the merchandises on their hand cards and traded cards by the merchandises on "ALL" price cards, who got most points wins!

184761.description:
Description from the publisher:

Customize your X-Wing squadron with colored X-Wing: Bases and Pegs. This accessory package comes with four small bases, ten small pegs, one large base, and three large pegs. All of them are made to the same specifications as standard X-Wing bases and pegs, and all of them are tournament-legal. Use these bases to identify the different ships in your squadron, to distinguish your squadron from your opponent's, or simply to add an extra touch of color to your battles for the galaxy.
184761.name: Star Wars: X-Wing Miniatures Game – Bases and Pegs

184762.name: Falling Stars: The Red Line
184762.description: Falling Stars: The Red Line is a tactical turn-based starship combat game set in Distant Sector of the Galaxy, where the last remnants of humanity fight for control of their future. Players choose a faction in Falling Stars, then assemble Star Fleets of customized Star Ships and engage in objective or mission driven space battles. Great war machines blast away in orbit of coven worlds, or in the vast dark of interstellar space. Explore uncharted systems in search of new riches or strategic advantages, all in an attempt to prevent the light of humanity from being swallowed up in the black of space.”

184763.description:
Fire Team: Red Eclipse is a new tactical system. Fire Team: Red Eclipse covers the Cold War Gone HOT in West Germany in the late 1980's and early 1990's. Fire Team: Red Eclipse is designed and developed by Steve Overton with Jon Southard, designer of the original Fire Team game, consulting and graphic design by Shayan Logan

Fire Team: Red Eclipse covers the US and Soviet forces fight on geomorphic maps that are represented at about 50-meter hexes and 2 - 5-minute turns.

Fire Team: Red Eclipse brings together mechanics to represent the OODA Loop, training and experience of military organizations, Command and Control of tactical combat units, random impulses based on the capabilities of your leaders on the map, intuitive game play based on the units responding to game play as soldiers do in actual situations, and the ability to create random events such as happen in small unit actions.

Couple the OODA Loop with the training and experience of each nations organizations in the series to create a unique blend of Command and Control with organizational traits. Tactical Event Cards add additional options for play, Command Points give you a varying number of orders per impulse - determined by the quality and condition of the leaders you currently have in play on the map. As the overall leader in the game, you can do whatever you want. You just won't be able to do it all at the same time. If one of your Command Point chits is drawn, you will have between 1 and three orders to issue. Those orders range from firing at the enemy to repairing support weapons and everything in between. That's all great but which orders do you give 'RIGHT NOW'? Each of us has a different idea about what's the most important thing to do at any given moment.

Leaders play the pivotal role in the game by creating orders, directing fire, providing a movement bonus, and assisting in rallying of broken/disrupted units. The state of your leaders on the map determines how many orders they can give each impulse during the turn. The organization of the nationality you have determines the number of orders you may get in an impulse. The player who can utilize his leaders to the greatest effect will usually be the winner. Usually, because nothing is ever 100% certain in Kontact Now.

Weaponry has not been left out of the game. All weapons of the era are in the game. All weapons systems in the series have been created using the same formulas. This allows each unit - weapons system - to be created with it's own unique values in relation to the other weapons of that same weapons class over the past 70+ years and into the future. Armor penetration values are constant throughout the series as are armor defensive values; for all vehicles and helicopters. Each weapons class has been exhaustively researched to give you the best unit values to work with. You don't have to worry about the weapons and the systems. All you have to worry about is using them in a winning combination.

Fire Team: Red Eclipse will include Off-Map Artillery, night rules, engineer obstacles (mines, wire, bunkers, trenches), multi-level buildings, rubble, fires, roadblocks, helicopter, Close Air Support (CAS), Antitank Guided Missiles, Surface to Air Missiles, Man Portable Air Defense systems, with both high and low unit counter density scenarios, exiting the map, all of varying degrees of complexity. Special rules governing helicopter and column movement activation, as well as snipers, medics, wounded and vehicles with multiple weapons systems.

Asymmetrical Victory Conditions combined with the Tactical Event Cards and concealment counters, random CAS attack packages, random size artillery missions, and Opportunity Fire adds a heavy layer of Fog of War to the system.

Because of the random chit draw for each impulse during a turn, the series is extremely solitaire friendly.

KN very much adheres to the chaos gaming method. This is not an "I take a turn/ You take a turn" game. This is random events, varying length impulses per turn, surprises at every moment kind of a game with an intuitive set of rules. It is not so random that you have nothing to do but sit back and let the game play itself. The choices are there every impulse for the gamer to impact game play. Tactical Event Cards can be played at any time, no matter whose impulse it is. Game play gets so intense that the gaming table may crack!!

Good Hunting.
184763.name: Fire Team: Red Eclipse

184766.name: Rechen Fuchs
184766.description:
There are 3 number dice and 52 cards with bigger numbers.
Just draw the card, roll the dice and do the math so that you are the first who make correct calculations according to the card.
At the end of the game who have the most cards is the winner.

184767.name: Advantage Basketball
184767.description:
This is the fastest, most accurate basketball game on the market today. Zone and man-to-man defenses are your options. You become coach and player at the same time. Learn to recognize all types of offenses and defenses as you try to outscore your opponent. A mobile spinner decides your position on the court - you determine your game strategy. Both offensive & defensive rebounds occur; shots are blocked and shots are made, fouls are committed and foul shots are taken; you may take the hook shot, jump shot, or set shot and you may dribble, pass or shoot. A scoreboard is provided for score, quarters, and time outs. You determine your own defense and what offense to use against your opponent. Call the shots yourself when you play Advantage Basketball. (from brochure)

Play is advanced through a special "mobile spinner" with a different disk for each position on the court, the detailed playbook and strategy.

184768.description:
How Do I Use a Tournament Kit?

Tournament Kits are designed for use with our competitive games, such as Warhammer: Diskwars, and they can be used in several ways. These kits include prize support and promotional material designed to support competitive or casual tournament play at local retailers. Run an eight-week tournament series or league, use the prizes to support a single, large tournament, or host a weekly casual game night. Tournament Kits also come with a guide that provides tips and ideas on how to run a great event.

Exclusive Scenarios!

Each Spring 2015 Warhammer: Diskwars Tournament Kit comes with eight copies of the exclusive Bloodgreed scenario. Scenarios are a great way to shake up your local players’ habits or introduce a new experience to your community. Use the scenarios during your event, making players use them for one round or the entire tournament, or introduce them in your own creative way. No matter how you use the scenarios, make sure to give them away as prizes before the end of the season!

What’s in the Spring 2015 Warhammer: Diskwars Tournament Kit?

Each Spring 2015 Warhammer: Diskwars Tournament Kit comes with exciting prizes and materials to help tournament organizers:

Eight copies of the Bloodgreed scenario
Two copies of an alternate art Karl Franz disc
Seventeen copies of an alternate art Skeleton Warriors disc
Four Empire card boxes depicting Karl Franz
A promotional poster featuring Karl Franz
One informational pamphlet on running a tournament or league
184768.name: Warhammer: Diskwars – Spring 2015 Tournament Kit

184769.name: Advantage Hockey
184769.description:
From the publisher:
This educational game depicts the actual high-speed excitement of the world's fastest sport. It is perfect for the beginner and advanced player or fan. All the strategic moves and fast action of hockey are provided for you. You can pass, skate or shoot - slapshot, wrist shot or backhand. Penalties can be called against you, and you can use the power play when your opponent is penalized. A scoreboard is provided for goals, periods and penalty time. The board play simulates every kind of action just like a real game on the ice. You create your own strategy and action.

Play is advanced through a special "mobile spinner" with a different disk for each position on the ice, the detailed playbook and strategy.

184770.name: Advantage: Tennis – The Game of Singles
184770.description:
The most complete detailed game of singles ever created. Designed to provide great entertainment while teaching all the basic fundamentals of the game. A mobile spinner decides your position on the court - you determine your game strategy. Advantage, Tennis is perfect for every level of competition, from beginner to expert. You serve, lob, volley and smash to strategic points on the court. You play backcourt and net. You hit and return shots from every spot on the court. Keep score by point, game and set - even tie-breakers. A booklet of rules, illustrated shots, court diagrams, and other instructional material is provided.(from brochure)

Play is advanced through a special "mobile spinner" with a different disk for each position on the court, the detailed playbook and strategy.

184771.name: Angry Town: The Super Ultra Violent Children's Card Game For Adults
184771.description:
Angry Town: The Super Ultra Violent Children's Card Game For Adults is a Card Game made to simulate Fighting Games. We give players the opportunity to build up a Meter to make attacks stronger, Chain together incredible combos, and Blast opponents away with the BLAST Attack!

The Mayor of Angry Town has caused a massive amount of chaos and anarchy all thoughout the Lovely Town of Angry Town. However, amidst all of the unrest comes opportunity. The citizens are now free to realize their dreams, but they need to get some people out of the way, namely the Mayor. To realize their ambitions they will need the Mayor out of the way, or on their side. But the Mayor is a tough sell, and many seek an audience with him. How will the citizenry overcome this obsticle? The only way to know is to jump in and play!

Angry Town is a 2 Player game that is easy to learn and easy to play. The game (or Match) is played in 4 Phases: the Attack Phase, Defend Phase, Draw Phase, and the End Phase. One Player (or Fighter) is always on the Attack and one is always on the Defense and each Fighter will be switching between those Phases throughout the Match. Fighters will draw 7 cards and use those cards for both attack and defense, and the only way to draw back up to 7 (or enter the Draw Phase) is to declare End Phase one after the other.

To begin a Match Players will choose one of 8 Fighters: a Ninja Howler Monkey, a Failed Martial Artist Bum, a Quack Doctor, an Angry Nerd, a Demented Girl Scout, a Baby Mob Boss, a Luchador Rabi, and a Nun, each with their own Ability that gives them a edge over their opponent. As the game progresses Fighters will build up a Meter that can be used for a CCCCombo Breaker!!!, power up an attack, or fill it all the way up to FINISH the opponent with the BLAST Attack!

If you want to test out the game then come to our website and download our 2 Fighter Print N Play Demo, and see for yourself what makes Angry Town so livid.

There are 3 Modes of Play: "Classic Mode" (2 Player head-to-head), "Tag Team Mode" (2 Player head-to-head with 2 or 3 Fighters each), and "Chaos Mode" (a 3-8 Player Battle Royale!).

Come on in and play! And to everyone...Welcome to Angry Town, where everyone is happy, happy to kick your ass and stomp you into the ground!

184772.name: Kids in Time
184772.description:
From the Introduction:

Dr. Wanda Wilson couldn't understand it. All of the calculations were correct. She'd sent objects back in time, that was for sure. Not smart phones or radios, of course, but spoons and knives, sure! She'd sent animals back in time, but why couldn't she send people? People didn't cause paradox events, so they should be able to be sent, but each time, the team just sat in the Wilson Transform Box and nothing happened. It just didn't make sense.

Then, one night in the lab, Wanda's daughter Erika began walking around in the lab. She was supposed to be doing her homework, of course, but that was boring, and she began wandering around the lab. Dr. Wilson had decided to try sending a spoon back in time to witness the signing of the Declaration of Independence, something that had worked before. She looked on with horror as she saw young Erika in the Wilson Transform Box. Dr. Wilson's fear was not because Erika would be hurt, but that Erika would ruin the experiment. People couldn't be sent back! Nothing would happen!

To Wanda's amazement, she was wrong. Erika disappeared along with the spoon! Would Wanda 's daughter return in the 24 hours allotted? Wanda hoped so. 24 hours later, Erika and the spoon re-appeared in the Box. Erika described what she had seen. She'd seen Ben Franklin just like in school! She'd seen John Hancock sign the document! The details were too detailed, too amazing to be wrong!

Wanda finally figured it out. Adults, with their knowledge of modern events, would cause the same paradox events that would be caused by advanced technology, but kids would be unobtrusive enough to prevent the paradox. With the help of Wanda and scientists like her, historians began planning to getting information they needed with Kids in Time.

184774.description:
Src:Card is a standalone 1-2 player (2-4 with expansion) card game that challenges players to build their own super robot core while attacking their opponent by writing code. Make your robot core as formidable as possible while creating code to attack and anticipate changes to your opponent's network. Src:Card is made for anyone interested in programming who has a love of gaming. Birthed from a love of German style boardgames, computer strategy games and too much time programming, Src:Card incorporates real coding concepts that are challenging for experts and easy to learn for beginners.

In Src:Card players have statement (method, bug and structure) cards and cybernetic core cards in their hand throughout the game. At the beginning of a turn a player will draw a new card. A player has the opportunity to harden the core of his/her robot's cybernetic core by adding nodes and firewall components. Each player must balance increased strength attributes against the vulnerabilities that new core cards present. Each player desires to harden his/her robot's core as much as possible while delaying the eight card "boot-up" threshold.

At the same time, players are creating code using actual programming items to defeat their opponent's super robot. The placement of different loops, varying conditional statements and a multitude of functions allows each player to create dynamic, ever changing instructions of attack against their opponent. All components can be nested and with the addition of expansion packs, new functions and additional players are added to the game.

When a player has passed the 8-card "boot-up" threshold, their robot is alive and is open to attack from its opponents. Should an opponent defeat your robot, they will be victorious. However should you do the same, you will neutralise the threat of that nation’s super robot and claim victory for your realm!
184774.name: Src:Card

184775.name: Karma Crystals: Elemental Battle
184775.description:
Use The New Rock, Paper, Scissors Mechanic To Score!

You can travel down life through good deeds or bad deeds, but karma will follow you either way. In Elemental Battle, your best tactic is to collect that bad karma now and give it to your opponents to get the win.

This 4th entry into the Karma Crystals game collection adds a rock, paper, scissors mechanic that works with SIX elemental icons for a whole new dimension to the game. You also get 11 new monster elemental cards for your collector’s deck!

Collect elemental battle shards into your ACTIVE area, then use them to battle your opponents through ONE of THREE battle actions. You can CAPTURE their ACTIVE battle shards into your SCORE area, MOVE their ACTIVE battle shards to your ACTIVE area, or TRANSFER battle shards from their SCORE areas to the general SUPPLY area, accessible to all players. Don’t worry… you can still pass your bad karma to other players. It wouldn’t be Karma Crystals without Karma Crystals!

You will either roll or battle on each turn. Roll dice to match with a monster elemental card and collect elemental battle shards that match your dice into you ACTIVE area, or battle to score shards. If you score 11 or more elemental battle shards, that triggers the end the game and a winner is determined at the end of that round!

In addition to the unique dice matching game mechanic, a unique auto player system is also used to facilitate up to EIGHT total players per game. The game also provides an easy way to track multiple game wins for playoffs in case you have more than 15 to 20 minutes to play. No paper score cards and pencil needed - the 96 elemental battle shards are all you need to battle your opponents and build your score.

184776.name: Karma Crystals: Swarm
184776.description:
Score Game Points As The Swarm Surrounds You, Or Escape!

You can travel down life through good deeds or bad deeds, but karma will follow you either way. In Swarm, your bestactic is to collect that bad karma now and swarm your opponents with karma crystals to get the win.

This 5th entry into the Karma Crystals game collection adds a zombie swarm type of game mechanic and a set of boards used to maneuver it against other players to win. You also get 10 new monster elemental cards for your collector’s deck!

Collect elemental shards and karma crystals from the swarm, but be careful. You are limited on attacks against them. Use the swarm for your benefit, but don’t be caught by it as other players use it against you!

As you build your collection of elemental shards and karma crystals, you can trigger the end of the game, but be careful not to do this before you are sure of the win.

In addition to the unique dice matching game mechanic, a unique auto player system is also used to facilitate up to EIGHT total players per game. The game also provides an easy way to track multiple game wins for playoffs in case you have more than 15 to 45 minutes to play depending on the number of players. No paper score cards and pencil needed. Your game score is determined by the number of elemental shards and karma crystals you score.

184777.name: Unparalleled Heroines
184777.description:
From publisher blurb:

In a world full of criminal organizations that promote fear and oppression, a group of five ladies fights back. The Masked Menagerie responds to everything from bank robberies to drug smuggling and kidnappings. These super-heroines range from flying scientists to wealthy mind readers, but all of them are ready to fit as an ally or opponent in your campaign!

184778.name: Amazons of Valsuum
184778.description:
From publisher blurb:

Journey to the Dying World of Valsuum, where a once great and technologically advanced and spacefaring people have fallen to barbarism and cruelity and death rule the day.

Amazons of Valsuum takes place after the fall of the 'Gods of Air & Water' as the players recover from their ordeals and plunged into an ongoing battle between the Zandgia and the Amazons who wage pirate raids from massive sky ships. Prisoners, Wanderers, Slaves, Champions, Saviors ... which of these will the players be called after they finish their fight with the Amazons of Valsuum.

Amazons of Valsuum is a 22 page Planetary Romance, Swords & Sandals style adventure for the White Star RPG system and is suitable for players of the second or third level.

184779.name: Last Rites
184779.description:
From publisher blurb:

Knowledge Check is a product line for players and gamemasters. Each book is a collection of rules and information designed to add a little knowledge to any fantasy campaign, focusing on a particular aspect of the skill system and adding depth and breadth to your play experience.

Knowledge Check: Last Rites will take you down the dark roads that lead beyond the veil that parts life and death. An extensive discussion of funerary rites, both celebratory and punitive, joins with grisly archetypes, spells, and gear to see characters off to the great beyond…and make sure they stay there.

184780.name: Dark Assembly
184780.description:
Welcome to the assembly of darkness!

In Dark Assembly, you become a member of the Diet of the world of darkness and receive tributes from supporters. Also, you earn money if you sell them on the black market. However, the VIPs controlling the assembly will require players to pay tributes to them.

In the town where have spiteful intentions, how much money may you get? In the world of darkness, you can do various thing, such as defying the VIPs.

Dark Assembly is a worker placement game that can also be played in solitaire mode.

184781.name: Kender Du Typen?
184781.description:
Kender Du Typen? is based on the Danish DR TV-show of the same name.

In the game, players try to become the best lifestyle expert, by answering various questions.
The questions in the game are divided into two categories: questions about how well you know your friends, and general questions about lifestyles.

184782.description:
Who sang “Love Me Tender”? Who is the author of Faust? What was the name of Frodo’s uncle?
Voobrazhariy: Stars is a new exciting game about guessing celebrities, both real and fictional ones. Each turn a new player must use one minute to describe as many famous personalities as possible by inventing intuitive word associations, recalling historic events or parodying stars. Be creative, resourceful and fast to become the main star of the evening!

Key game features:

New Super game from the series «Voobrazhariy» series – fast-paced word association game!
Now your task is to describe as many famous people and characters as possible.
A cool opportunity to play in two ways: every player for himself or team play.
You can mix Voobrazhariy: Star cards with other versions of the series to get more than 9800 entries!




Russian description:
Какой певец предлагал выпить за любовь? Кто сжёг второй том «Мёртвых душ»? Как звали хозяйку Крыски-Лариски?
«Воображарий: Звёзды» — новая увлекательная игра на загадывание и разгадывание знаменитостей, реально существовавших и вымышленных. Каждый ход выбирается новый ведущий, который должен за одну минуту объяснить другим как можно больше известных личностей, придумывая интуитивные ассоциации, вспоминая исторические события или пародируя звёзд. Будьте креативны, находчивы и расторопны и тогда обязательно станете главной звездой вечера!

Ключевые особенности игры:

Новая супер-игра из серии «Воображарий» - игра в ассоциации на скорость!
Теперь твоя задача угадать как можно больше знаменитых людей и персонажей, существующих или существовавших в реальности, а также вымышленных.
Крутая возможность играть двумя способами: каждый сам за себя или объединиться в команды.
Карты игры «Воображарий.Звезды» можно перемешать с другими версиями серии и получить более 9800 заданий!
184782.name: Voobrazhariy: Stars

184783.name: Big Brain Bang
184783.description: Big Brain Bang makes it possible to peek inside the human brain to see what happens there. Together with the other players, you take on the roles of competing thoughts that seek to take control of as many neurons as possible. A brain model built of cardboard neuron network tiles will appear right on your gaming table. By the end of the game, the owner of the biggest network wins!

184784.name: Dramatic License
184784.description:
User summary:

In Dramatic License, characters are built around personality and concept. These traits should be the driving force behind character actions and goals. Players that drive character actions that deviate from personality and concept receive significant penalties. Personality in particular is well-defined and categorized. Good play is defined as performing fast and interesting actions.

Characters have twelve Attributes in three classes: Physical (Might, Toughness, Reflexes, Size); Mental (Intuition, Smarts, Willpower, Heart); and Other (Appeal, Fan Factor, Luck, Power). There are three Derived Attributes (Basic Damage Resistance, Popularity, Recovery). Attributes are purchased from a points pool. Characters can eschew Armor in favor of the Scantily Clad Bonus.

Characters also have definitive abilities (Classic Bits) and Skills. Combat is driven by Skill use. Because the game focuses on cinematic events, most combat Skills are visually impressive and exciting, and much of the rules is devoted to numerous combat Skills (some are quite crazy). Skill resolution follows a familiar formula of Attribute and Skill with die roll compared to a target difficulty.

184785.name: Champions of ZED
184785.description:
From the back cover

Open ended, world-building adventure was the only kind of tabletop role play gaming at the time it was introduced in 1974. The rules for those "sandbox" campaigns lie scattered, primarily across three little paperback booklets, full of obscure stats, unexplained tables, and vague references to other rule sets - not included!

Champions of ZED puts it all together, clearly, and under one cover, along with notes from long lost drafts, and house-rules from the games' two original designers. At last, enjoy the endless possibilities of Zero Edition Dungeoneering!

184786.name: Dreamwalker: Musings

rpg.9371: Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams

184786.description:
A free demo version of Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams

From the document:

Dreamwalker: Musings is an attempt to introduce people to some of the concepts of Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams. In this demo, you play a Dreamwalker assigned to Crystal Bayou, a regional chapter house of Project Dreamwalker. At night you enter the dreams of others and attempt to rid troubled minds of the Taeniid infestation.

This demo is designed for people already familiar with roleplaying game terminology.

184787.name: Buried Treasure

rpg.9371: Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams

184787.description:
Buried Treasure is distributed as a ten-page DOC adventure and a one-page PDF keyed map.

Module summary:

Ben Grady married his wife, Eva, just after they graduated high school back in the 50’s. To support them, Ben enlisted in the army, retired, worked in the civil service on base and then retired again. He and his wife were very happy together until she died a year ago at the age of 67.

Ben loved his wife dearly and has been unable to cope with her death. He has been spiraling into depression ever since. After much urging, his son finally convinced him to seek help and his therapist recommended him to the Project.

184788.name: What Time Is It?

rpg.9371: Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams

184788.description:
Buried Treasure is distributed as a ten-page DOC adventure and a one-page image ("Noise on the Roof").

Module summary:

Arnold Parnell is normally a friendly man. He is balding, short and stocky and his pants ride low on his waist, exposing a perpetual "plumber’s crack". He enjoys watching sports such as football and boxing with "the boys" down at the local bar.

Arnold is a craftsman by trade. He has always been good with his hands and currently works as a live-in maintenance man for a small apartment building in the city. Lately he has felt overworked and underpaid. He has also been suffering bouts of insomnia and the lack of sleep has made him gruff and irritable. He was referred to the chapter after several Union-paid therapist visits.

184789.name: The Rebel and Other Types
184789.description:
From the Introduction:

Carl Jung first coined the term archetype in 1919 in an essey called Instinct and the Unconscious. His idea was that there are primeval types in our subconscius which form into images in individual minds. These images are different, but the archetype can be recognized.

The Rebel and Other Types collects ten common archetypes into a form playable in roleplaying games. These types should be usable in any game, and are meant to complement character creation rather than replace it.

184790.name: Dreamwalker: Errata

rpg.9371: Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams

184790.description:
User summary:

Official rules Errata from the game designers. Corrections are listed by page number (reference the original rules).

Two versions were produced: July 2002 (DOC format) and February 2004 (PDF format). The 2004 version everything the 2002 version does, plus additions, and is preferred.

184791.name: Redefining Resisted Skill Rolls

rpg.9371: Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams

184791.description:
From the document:

It has been brought to our attention that parts of our system, namely the rules for resolving initiative and other resisted Skill rolls, are felt by some to be too cumbersome during actual play. Unless otherwise noted, the following rules for resolving Skill rolls supersede the ones listed in the Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams core rulebook.

Now, when making a normal Skill roll, the player wants to roll as close to his Base Chance as he can without going over. When making a resisted Skill roll, the character who succeeds with the highest die roll wins the contest.

184792.name: Redefining the Nature of Fluff

rpg.9371: Dreamwalker: Roleplaying in the Land of Dreams

184792.description:
From the document:

Fluff are extraneous touches and details that can be used to reinforce the impression that the characters are in a dream. Fluff usually has no bearing on the denouement and most often manifests as things that have left a mark on the Dreamer's subconscious mind.
